annotation.TEXT: As you can probably tell from this menu, Mega Man has quite the ridiculous arsenal at his disposal; He has nearly every single weapon from almost every single game in the classic series. The only things he doesn't have are the various support items (Item 1, Carry, etc), the MM9 and 10 arsenals, and the Dimensions' weapons from the WonderSwan game.

As another interesting note: Although Mega Man himself doesn't have access to support items, he can still call on Rush, Beat, or Tango for some additional help. Once summoned, they'll follow you around and attack nearby enemies. Although you can only have one with you at a time, your helpers are essentially invincible (they can easily come back after falling down pits or getting caught up on other hazards).

All three helpers also have their own unique Super Adapter forms as well. Beat's is easily the best of these (for obvious reasons), though that's not to say Rush and Tango's are bad by any means. It's just that they're easily eclipsed by Beat's power of "hover over everything."
No, you didn't imagine that. I just died by clipping off a moving platform that I clearly landed on. The best part is that this happens not only once...
...But twice in a row. This isn't something that's limited to this stage or these specific platforms, either. This can happen with almost any type of moving platform in any given level.

In any case, it's time for the basic run-down: I'll be playing as Mega Man for this run (considering he's the most finished/useful of the four playable characters). Mega Man initially controls..."somewhat" like his original self. He retains his slide and the chargeable buster, but both of them have some strange quirks. Aside from the slide not always working, you can actually hold down the button to perform an infinite slide (much like in Rockbot). The buster is a different story however, mainly because its charge builds up automatically, rather than requiring you to hold down the button.

Oh, and the fact that all of them have two lifebars (similar to some of the bosses in the MM Zero series) doesn't really help them much. Even if you don't use Top Spin, they still go down relatively fast to just about any other multi-hit weapon.

Just to note real quick: What seems like a jumpcut after Plasma Man dies is actually a part of this demo. Even though the intro boss had a somewhat elaborate (if seemingly unfinished) explosion for when it died, none of the Robot Masters blow up when you deplete their health. Instead, it sends you straight back to the stage select in a mere instant.

There's not a whole lot to say about the bosses in this game (save for a select few). While they all have their own unique patterns and attacks, they're all still just as susceptible to the Thunder Beam and Top Spin. There's a few that might require you to jump over them or avoid projectiles occasionally, but for the most part, you can literally stand next to almost any boss and Top Spin them to death with little to no effort.

Since the plasma spheres weren't enough, we now have the asteroids from Star Man's stage to contend with. Though they move slower here, they have a very annoying habit of spawning right above you just as you're about to jump to another platform.

Anyways, this is the demo for "Mega Man Next Remix," a browser based fan-game. Since I had to rush through the title screen, I'll do my best to clear up any confusion with some info in the description. Feel free to read that if you haven't already.

As you can see, the Top Spin has gotten a massive buff in this game: You can spin while on the ground, you can hold the button to retain the spin, and you can move freely while using it. All of these traits combined easily make it the most broken weapon in the game. It even gets to the point where you can nearly breeze through a majority of levels with little to no effort.

As for the stages, considering this game is still a demo, I'll essentially be doing every possible level for now. This includes the intro stage (seen here) and the 20 Robot Master levels. Despite this being a rather lengthy task at first glance, the levels actually go by pretty quickly (if mainly due to Thunder Beam/Top Spin).

Oh boy, I can hear the Transformers fans raging now. From what I understand, this game's version of "Shark Man" is a complete rip-off of the Sharkticons from the 5th Transformers movie in 1986. It's not like the creator is hiding this fact, either. Shark Man looks exactly like a Sharkticon (and even has an attack where he blatantly transforms into a Decepticon, familiar sound cue and all), and even his stage resembles the place where they first show up in the movie. Hell, even the music is ripped directly from the movie as well (albeit, in rather awful quality).

Time to start the final game from the 1K Subscriber vote. If it seems like I'm rushing through this intro a bit quicker than usual, it's because I am. This is mostly to skip to the title screen's music (which I believe is a Disturbed song), lest I get slammed with a copyright notice. Then again, the music output on this game is so terrible that I doubt that YouTube can even pick up on it.

Plasma Man's stage is one of the few levels in the game where it's actually a good idea to use other weapon types. Specifically, the Time and Flash Stopper from MM2 and 4. The reason for this is due to the "plasma spheres" scattered through-out this stage. They basically act like bigger versions of the firebars from the Mario series, only they tend to move quite fast. Given the whole level has a "zero gravity" effect, the timing to get by these is way more frustrating than necessary. It also doesn't help that they take roughly 25% of your life if you bump into them, which means you can't just shrug them off either.

Despite having a wide array of weapons, there are only two that are worth using above all others: The Thunder Beam from MM1, and the Top Spin from MM3. The reason for this is because every enemy in this game (including the bosses) lacks invincibility frames. This makes weapons that pass through or linger on enemies far more effective than those that don't. For the Thunder Beam, that's standard game, but the Top Spin might need some explanation...

Although I should have pointed this out earlier, the Rush Jet and Marine segments in this game are rather annoying. Aside from limiting you to the standard buster, they tend to overstay their welcome more often than not. Other times however, their placement is downright inconsistent (such as in later levels, where you'll get on a brief Rush Jet segment without encountering enemies, only to go right back to doing standard platforming about half a screen later).
